div.p: The original transcription is not available.

Probably the most important issue of the internal politics of Mr. Gigurtu´s government is the adjustment of the Jewish Question. It is not only an important question of the internal politics, which would be no more than a logical resolution of the new orientation of the Romanian politics overall and which would adjust the situation of Jews in Romania towards the new order. It is a much more important problem, since it reaches maybe way too far into the overall economic structure of modern Romania.

I have to point out right at the beginning that it is not only about the fact that one or the other of the important industrial or business company is owned by Jews and that a radical Aryanization is needed. All that would not be such a big problem and could be carried out under certain circumstances, following the example of Germany, radically but without any severe damages to the economy. The problem, however, is much more complicated due to the exceptional situation of Romania. In this wealthy country is the majority of the capital in the companies of non-Romanian origin. Mostly it is Jewish, but also British, French, from Belgium and from Netherlands.

This side of the situation is the one which can bring major issues for the Romanian economy if not handled very carefully. Voices are growing louder, saying that the British capital has already been withdrawn, since Romania is seen as a country definitely in the interest area of the German Reich. As proof of this claim, it is reported that the British sold at the last moment participation in some of the most important oil companies to Russia, even below value, just to upset both Romania and Germany.

Therefore, there is a possibility that the sources of foreign capital – the sources so much needed for a country as Romania which is weak on capital, since the Romanian population does not invest the money and the money is not within the estates and houses [...] – will be suddenly cut off and thus a new and much stronger financial and economic crisis will occur. The local Jews, afraid, have already cut off any further businesses, theydo not dislodge goods that accumulate at customs, and they do not make any new trades or transaction. They are gathering money and investing it into volatile values, such as diamonds, dollar bills, etc. It seems to me that they are not even trying to sabotage anything; rather they are worried for the future of Jews in Romania, which will certainly to be very difficult. The crisis is definitely just around the corner, since the German capital cannot come into effect straight away and if Romania was under threat of losing another territory to Hungary and Bulgaria, after already losing Bessarabia and northern Bukovina, the extend of the crisis could be devastating. Current national budget of about 130 billion is already a heavy load for this diminished territory and if there were to be other civil servants returning to Romania, those from
the territories Romania could lose, the financial burden would be way too big for the rest of Romania.

These are serious perspectives, it is not only a sheer Jewish misconception and propaganda to protect their positions, therefore the solutions the government is about to take when it comes to the Jewish Question are very intensely awaited at this moment.

If the solution is rational time-wise and also prepared (and so far there are no causes, even among the smaller officers, already manifesting dissatisfaction of the anti-Jewish sentiment to expect the government to act hastily), the chances that the solution of the Jewish Question will bring on a central crisis will be at least smaller.

However, if the government does not proceed carefully, it could be facing such major failures as the nationalist government of the late Octavian Goga did. His government had to be removed after only two months of its existence; therefore Romania was threatened by a major economical and financial crisis. Very similar aspects are now reappearing, awaiting the solutions to the Jewish Question, therefore an objective observer needs to be thinking of this unpleasant precedent [...] however, it cannot be forgotten that the government of Mr. Gigurtu has a very practical national economist and financial expert – the Prime Minister himself. He must be aware

of the difficulties connected to this situation and therefore he will definitely proceed very rationally and as carefully as it is necessary, given the circumstances. Moreover, the Minister of the National Economy, who is at the same time a well-known national economist, oversees all the so called economical resorts, thus he has the necessary possibilities of a united progress and can avoid any conflicts in the competencies of resorts.
Based on all the mentioned reasons I can express my hope that the government will solve the urgent and difficult problems without any major shakedowns, given they take reasonable approach.
Made in 6 copies, 4 of them for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 1 copy for the army attaché and 1 copy to be stored within the records.
